div.note: They say that the Prince of Condé slept soundly on the eve of the Battle of Rocroi. Well, in the first place, he was exhausted. In the second, he had already issued all the necessary orders and arranged what had to be done in the morning.
Don Abbondio, instead, knew nothing except that the next day would be a day of battle, so he spent much of the night in inner torment.
To go ahead and perform the marriage, despite the thugs’ warnings and threats, was an alternative he did not wish to contemplate.
To confide to Renzo what had happened and try to find some way with him…God help us!

“Don’t breathe a word. And if you do talk…snick,” one of the bravi had said. With the sound of that snick echoing in his ears, rather than consider disobeying the order, Don Abbondio regretted even mentioning it to Perpetua.
Run away?
To where?
And then?
So many obstacles! So many things to ponder!
With each discarded possibility, the poor man turned over in his bed.
The best or rather least bad option apparently was to buy time, by putting Renzo off for as long as possible.

He recalled that in only a few days, the period would begin when the Church calendar prohibited weddings. “If I could keep that overgrown boy waiting for a few days, I’d have two months’ breathing room, and a lot can happen in two months.”

He weighed the excuses he could muster. While they might have seemed paltry, he kept assuring himself that his authority would make them appear weighty, and that his years of experience would give him a significant advantage over the ignorant youth. “We’ll see,” he told himself. “He’s worried about his sweetheart while I’m worried about saving my skin. The person with the most at stake here is me, not to mention that I’m better informed.

‘My dear boy, if you’re feeling so hot and bothered, what can I say except that I have no wish to get caught in the middle.’ ” Having thus settled on a single thought, he was finally able to close his eyes. But what a sleep it was! And what dreams!
Populated by bravi, Don Rodrigo, Renzo, footpaths, cliffs, escapes, chases, decrees, and gunshots.
To wake up after a catastrophe and in the middle of a predicament is a bitter moment indeed.

The mind, just stirring, reverts to its customary notions of the peaceful former life. But then the thought of the new state of affairs makes a rude entrance, rendered all the more unpleasant by rapid comparison.

Having tasted that painful moment, Don Abbondio immediately reviewed the plans he had devised during the night, confirmed and rearranged them, then got out of bed and began to wait for Renzo with a combination of impatience and dread.
Lorenzo, or Renzo, as everyone called him, did not keep Don Abbondio waiting.

As soon as the hour seemed right to appear before the priest without being too intrusive, he went, with the joyful exuberance of a twenty-year-old man who on that day is going to marry the girl he loves.

He had been orphaned since adolescence, and was a silk-worker by trade: a family legacy, so to speak. It was a trade that years earlier had been quite lucrative, but had lately fallen into decline, although not so much that a skilled worker could not make an honest living.

Every day there was less and less work, but the constant exodus of workers, drawn to neighboring states by promises, privileges, and higher wages, ensured that there were still jobs for those who stayed behind.
In addition, Renzo owned a small plot of farmland that others worked, as did he himself when the spinning mill was idle. So you could say that, for his station in life, he was comfortable.

And although that year’s harvest might have been leaner than the previous year’s, and the first signs of a famine were appearing, our young man, from the moment he had laid his eyes on Lucia, had become a good administrator; he had managed to set aside sufficient provisions, and did not have to contend with hunger.

Now he appeared before Don Abbondio all dressed up, with colored feathers in his cap, the fine handle of his dagger sticking out of his trouser pocket, and an attitude both festive and cocky, common to even the most mild-mannered men in those days.
Don Abbondio’s hesitant, mysterious welcome made a singular contrast to the youth’s jovial and resolute manner.
“He must have something on his mind,” Renzo said to himself. Then, aloud, “I have come, Reverend Father, to know when it would be most convenient for you to meet us in church.”
“What day were you thinking?”
“What do you mean, what day? Don’t you remember that we set the date for today?”
“Today?” Don Abbondio replied, as if he were hearing it for the first time.
“Today? Today?…You’ll have to be patient. I can’t do it today.”
“What do you mean you can’t do it today?
What happened?”
“First of all, you see, I don’t feel well.”
“I’m sorry to hear it. But this will take so little time and so little effort…”
“And then, and then…”
“And then what?”
“And then there are complications.”
“Complications?
What kind of complications?”
“You’d have to be in our shoes to know the obstacles that come up in these matters, all the things that have to be taken into account.
My only concern is to get rid of the obstacles, smooth the way, to do other people’s pleasure, and I end up neglecting my duties. I am too good. Then I have to hear criticism, and worse!”
“For the love of heaven, don’t keep me guessing. Tell me plain and clear, what’s the problem?”
“Do you have any idea how many formalities are involved in doing a marriage properly?”
“How could I not,” said Renzo, starting to get upset, “when it’s been making me crazy for the past few days!
But didn’t you take care of everything? Didn’t you do everything you were supposed to?”
“Everything, everything, you think it’s so simple. I’m the one that’s a fool, neglecting my duties to spare other people the trouble.
But now…enough, I know what I’m talking about.
We poor priests are stuck between a rock and a hard place. You’re so impatient, but you have my sympathies, my poor lad. And my superiors…let me stop right there, some things shouldn’t be said.
But we’re the ones that get caught in the middle.”
“Just explain these formalities that have to be taken care of, as you say, and we can take care of them right away.”
“Have you ever heard of impedimenta dirimenta?”
“Huh?”
“Error, conditio, votum, cognatio, crimen, cultus disparitas, vis, ordo, ligamen, honestas, si sis affinis,” Don Abbondio began, counting on his fingertips.
“Are you making fun of me?” the young man interrupted.
“How am I supposed to understand your latinorum?”
“Well, if you don’t know things, you should be patient and listen to those that do.”
“Enough!”
“Come now, dear Renzo, don’t go losing your temper. I’m ready to…to do everything I’m supposed to.
I…I want you to be happy. I’m fond of you.
You know, when I think how well you were doing…what more did you want?
Then you had to come up with this nonsense of getting married!”
“Nonsense, Father?” exploded Renzo, with a face both shocked and irate.
“What I mean to say is, what I mean to say…just be patient.
I want you to be happy!”
“In other words…”
“In other words, my son, it’s not my fault. I’m not the one who writes the rules.
Before celebrating a matrimony, we are required to make many, many inquiries, to be sure there are no impediments.”
“Enough now, tell me once and for all, what impediment has come up?”
“Patience, patience, it’s not the kind of thing I can explain off the top of my head.
I’m sure there’s nothing, at least I hope there isn’t. Nevertheless, we have to look into this.
The rules are crystal clear. Antequam matrimonium denunciet…”
“Enough with the Latin, I said.”
“But I need to explain…”
“Didn’t you already take care of this?”
“Not everything that I was supposed to.”
“Why not? Why did you tell me everything was ready? Why wait until…”
“There you go. Criticizing me for being too good.
I did everything I could to speed things along for you, but…but now they’ve come to me…enough, I know my reasons.”
“And what do you expect me to do?”
“Be patient for a few more days.
My dear son, a few days are hardly an eternity. Be patient.”
“For how long?”
Don Abbondio thought, “We’re almost there,” and with an attitude more ceremonious than ever said, “Come now, in fifteen days I’ll try…I’ll manage…”
“Fifteen days! That’s a good one!
Everything you asked for has been done. The day is set, it arrives, and now you tell me to wait fifteen days!

Fifteen!” he continued in a louder, more cantankerous voice, extending his arm and punching his fist in the air, and who knows what other mischief that number would have sparked if Don Abbondio had not interrupted him, taken his other hand, and with a shy and solicitous tenderness said, “Come now, don’t get upset, for the love of heaven.
I’ll see, I mean I’ll try, in a week…”
“And what am I supposed to tell Lucia?”
“That it was my mistake.”
“And what will people say?”
“Go ahead and tell everyone that I made a mistake because I was too hasty, out of the goodness of my heart. Blame everything on me.
Can I make myself any clearer? Come now, it’ll just be a week.”
“And there won’t be other ‘impediments’?”
“When I say…”
“So be it. I’ll be patient for a week, but I’m warning you, after that, I don’t want to hear any more excuses.
Until then, my respects.”
Saying this, he left, making a shorter bow to Don Abbondio than usual, and giving him a look that was more expressive than reverential.
Renzo began walking toward the home of his betrothed, the first time he’d ever gone there reluctantly: Stewing in his anger, the more he thought about that conversation, the stranger it seemed.

The chilly and awkward welcome of Don Abbondio, his words both labored and impatient, the two gray eyes that, while he was speaking, kept flitting about, as if they were afraid to encounter the words coming out of his mouth, his pretending to be surprised by a marriage that had been expressly arranged, and above all his constant hinting at some momentous thing without saying what exactly it was. These circumstances as a whole led Renzo to think that Don Abbondio was hiding something from him.
He was about to turn around and demand a clear explanation when he looked up and saw Perpetua a few feet ahead, stepping into a garden not far from the rectory.
He called out to her while she was opening the gate, walked briskly to catch up, and detained her at the entrance. Thinking he could dig up something more concrete, he struck up a conversation.
“Good morning, Perpetua. I had hoped that today we’d be sharing our happiness.”
“God’s will be done, my Renzo.”

“Could you do me a favor? The reverend, that rascal, concocted some reasons for the delay that I’m having a hard time figuring out. Maybe you could do a better job of explaining why he can’t or won’t marry us today?”
“Me? What makes you think that I would know my master’s secrets?”
“I knew there was something fishy about this,” thought Renzo. And to bring that something to light, he went on. “Come now, Perpetua, we’re old friends. Tell me what you know. Give a boy a hand.”
“It’s a terrible thing to be born poor, my dear Renzo.”
“True,” he continued, feeling more confirmed in his suspicions. To get to the heart of the matter, he added, “True, but is it a priest’s job to mistreat the poor?”
“Listen, Renzo, I can’t say anything because…I don’t know anything. But what I can say is that my master doesn’t want to hurt you or anyone else. It’s not his fault.”
“Whose fault is it, then?” Renzo asked, feigning indifference but with his heart in his throat and his ears pricked.
“When I say I know nothing I mean…but in my master’s defense I will say one thing, because I hate to hear him accused of wanting to cause anyone harm.
The poor man! His only fault is that he is too good.
There is still some decency in this world of scoundrels, bullies, and other godless men…”
“Bullies? Scoundrels?” thought Renzo. “So he wasn’t talking about his superiors.”
“Come now,” he said, struggling to contain his growing agitation, “come now, you can tell me.”
“Ah, you want to make me talk, and I can’t because…I don’t know anything. When I say I don’t know anything it’s as if I were sworn to silence.
Torture me all you want; you still wouldn’t get a word out of me.
I’m off now. We’re both wasting our time here.”
With that she rushed into the rectory garden and closed the gate behind her.

Muttering goodbye, Renzo turned around very slowly so she wouldn’t notice where he was going. As soon as she was out of earshot, he quickened his pace and in a heartbeat was back at Don Abbondio’s door. He went in and headed straight for the parlor where he’d left the priest. Finding him still there, he went up to him boldly, eyes ablaze.
“What’s this?” cried Don Abbondio.
“Tell me the name of that scoundrel!” Renzo demanded, with the voice of a man determined to get an exact answer. “Who’s the bully that doesn’t want me to marry Lucia?”
“Wha-wha-what?” stuttered the poor man, caught by surprise. In an instant his face turned as weak and pale as a fleck of ash.
In the midst of his protests, he leapt up from his chair and ran for the door, but Renzo beat him to it, locked the door, and put the key in his pocket.
“Aha! Now are you ready to talk, Reverend Father?
Everyone knows my business except me.
Well, I want to know, too, by God.
Tell me his name!”
“Renzo, Renzo, for pity’s sake, think of what you’re doing. Think of your soul.”
“What I’m thinking is that I want to know right away, in this instant.”
As he said this, he placed his hand, unconsciously perhaps, on the handle of the dagger jutting from his pocket.
“Mercy me!” exclaimed Don Abbondio in a faint voice.
“I want to know.”
“Who told you…”
“Stop beating around the bush.
Out with it, and now.”
“Do you want to get me killed?”
“I want to know what I have a right to know.”
“But if I tell you, I’m dead.
Don’t I have the right to value my own life?”
“Enough of this. Now talk.”
Renzo uttered that talk with such vehemence and such a menacing face that Don Abbondio did not dare disobey him.
“Promise me, swear to me,” he said, “that you won’t tell anyone, that you’ll never say…”
“I promise I’ll do something you’ll regret if you don’t tell me his name right this instant!”
At this latest threat, Don Abbondio, wearing the expression of a man with forceps in his mouth, whimpered, “Don…”
“Don…” Renzo repeated, as if to help the patient spit out the rest. He was leaning over him now, his ear close to trembling mouth, his arms taut, his fists clenched behind his back.

“Don Rodrigo!” the prisoner blurted out, racing over those few syllables and slurring the consonants, partly out of agitation, partly because—in the effort to reconcile his two fears—he seemed to want to retract that name and make it disappear the moment he was forced to give it up.
“That dog!” Renzo shouted.
“How did he do it?
What did he say to you to…”
“Begging your pa-pardon?” Don Abbondio replied, almost indignantly. After making such a big sacrifice, he felt that Renzo owed him something in return.
“Begging your pardon?
I’d like to see what you would have done in my position. Me, who’s got nothing to do with the matter. Then you wouldn’t be entertaining such foolish ideas!”

He began to paint a dire picture of the awful encounter. As he spoke, he became more and more aware of the rage building in his body, which, until that moment, had been shrouded in fear. At the same time he noticed that amid the anger and confusion, Renzo was standing still, his head lowered. Don Abbondio continued freely, “Fine way for you to behave!
What a fine courtesy you’ve paid me!
A trick like this against an honest man, against your own priest! In his own home! At a holy place!
Nice behavior from you!
All to extract the source of my troubles—of your troubles!—from my mouth! I was hiding it from you out of prudence, for your own good.
And now that you know?
I’d like to see what you’re going to do to me…!
For the love of heaven, this is no laughing matter.
It’s not a question of right or wrong. It’s a question of power.
And when this morning I gave you some good advice?…You flew into a rage.
I was wise both for my sake and for yours. How could you?
Would you at least unlock the door? Give me the key?”

“Maybe I was wrong,” Renzo replied. His tone toward Don Abbondio had softened, but one could still hear his anger at the man he had discovered to be his enemy. “Maybe I was wrong, but place your hand over your heart and imagine what you would have done in my shoes…”
As he said this, he dug the key out of his pocket and went to open the door.

Don Abbondio followed him, and while Renzo was turning the key in the lock he went up to him and, with a serious, anxious look, raised the first three fingers of his right hand before his eyes, as if to offer some help in return. “Swear…”
“Maybe I was wrong, my apologies,” Renzo replied, opening the door and preparing to leave.
“Swear,” Don Abbondio insisted, grabbing the youth’s arm with a trembling hand.

“Maybe I was wrong,” Renzo repeated once more, breaking away from him and leaving in a rush, cutting short the dispute, which could have lasted for centuries, not unlike a literary or philosophical debate in which each side did little more than repeat its arguments.
“Perpetua!
Perpetua!” Don Abbondio shouted, after calling the fugitive back in vain.
Silence. Don Abbondio no longer knew what world he was living in.

More than once people more important than Don Abbondio had found themselves in such annoying predicaments, so uncertain of what action to take that they could think of no better remedy than to take to bed with a fever, a remedy Don Abbondio did not need to go looking for since it offered itself spontaneously.
The previous day’s scare, the sleepless night, the fear he felt in that moment, and anxiety over the future had their cumulative effect.

Groggy and exhausted, he could not get out of his chair. He started to feel a chill coming over him. Breathing heavily, he checked his fingernails for signs of a fever. From time to time he called out in a shaky, irritable voice, “Perpetua!”
Finally she arrived, a large cabbage under her arm, with a no-nonsense look on her face, as if nothing had happened.

I’ll spare the reader the complaints, the condolences, the accusations, the excuses, the back-and-forth of “It was you,” and “No, it wasn’t!” all the twists and turns, in other words, of that conversation.

Suffice it to say that Don Abbondio ordered Perpetua to lower the bar over the door and not to open it for any reason. If someone knocked, she was to reply from the window that the priest had taken to bed with a fever.
He then slowly climbed the stairs, saying at every other step, “Oh, woe is me.” Then he really did go to bed, which is where we shall leave him.
Meanwhile Renzo was walking home at a furious pace, without having decided on a course of action, but with an urge to do something strange and terrible.
The troublemakers, the tyrants, all those who wrong others in any way, are guilty not only of the wrongs they do but also of the way they pervert the minds of their victims.

Renzo was an easygoing youth averse to bloodshed, a pure-hearted boy who hated all intrigues. But in that moment thoughts of murder pulsed through his veins while his mind was dedicated solely to imagining an act of treachery.

He wanted to run to Don Rodrigo’s house, grab him by the throat, and…but he remembered that it was built like a fortress, guarded on the inside by bravi and on the outside by sentries. Only close friends and servants could enter freely, without being scrutinized from head to toe. An unknown laborer—especially Renzo—could never get in without being interrogated…On the other hand, he might be known all too well.

He then imagined taking out his musket, lying in wait behind a bush in case Don Rodrigo passed by alone. Losing himself in this fantasy with a fierce satisfaction, he imagined hearing one footstep, then another, lifting his head without making a sound, spotting the villain, leveling his musket, taking aim, firing, seeing him drop and breathe his last, cursing him, and running down the road to the border and safety.
“And Lucia?” No sooner had her name been cast across these sinister fantasies then in swarmed the better thoughts to which Renzo’s mind was more accustomed.

He remembered his last moments with his parents. He remembered God, the Blessed Mother, and the saints, and he thought back to the consolation he had felt so many times at being untainted by crime, at his horror whenever he heard talk of a murder. And he roused himself from that dream of bloodshed with feelings of shock and remorse, together with a sense of relief that all he had done was imagine it.
But to think of Lucia was to think of everything she evoked.
So many hopes, so many promises, a future they had dreamed of, which they had thought was secure, and the day they had longed for.
And how, with what words, could he deliver such news?
And what should he do then?
How could he marry her in the face of that evil tyrant’s power?
At the same time, not so much a suspicion as a troubling shadow crossed his mind.
Don Rodrigo’s act of outrage could only have been caused by a bestial passion for Lucia.
And Lucia?
The thought that she might have given him the smallest opportunity, the slightest enticement, was something he could not bear to contemplate for even a moment.
But was she aware of it?
Could Don Rodrigo have developed his sinister ardor without her knowledge?
Might he have gone that far without first approaching her in some way?
And Lucia had never said a word to him! To her future husband!
Preoccupied by these thoughts, he walked past his own house, which was in the center of the village, and headed toward Lucia’s, which was at the far end of town, or rather, slightly past it.
Her cottage had a small courtyard in front enclosed by a low wall that separated it from the street.
Renzo entered the courtyard and heard the steady buzzing of many voices coming from a room upstairs.
He imagined it must be the female friends and neighbors who had come to escort Lucia to the wedding, and did not want to appear before that gaggle with the news he wore on his body and on his face.
A little girl who was in the courtyard ran toward him crying out, “The groom! The groom!”
“Shhh, Bettina, shh!” said Renzo.

“Come here. Go upstairs to Lucia, take her to one side, and whisper into her ear…No one should hear or suspect anything…Tell her that I need to speak with her, that I’m waiting for her in the downstairs room, and to come right away.”
The little girl quickly climbed the stairs, happy and proud to have a secret mission to perform.
At that very moment Lucia was coming out of her room, all dressed up by her mother’s hands.

Her friends teased the bride, demanding that she show herself. She shielded herself, with that slightly aggressive modesty of peasant women, covering her face with her elbow, folding it toward her chest, and knitting her long dark eyebrows, while her mouth opened in a smile.

Her dark youthful hair, parted over her forehead on either side of a thin white line, was pulled behind her head and braided in many circles, which were pierced by long silver pins arranged like the rays of a halo, the way peasant women in the Milanese provinces still wear their hair today.

Around her neck she had a necklace of garnets alternating with gold filigree beads. She was wearing a floral brocade bodice, with the sleeves separated and tied by pretty ribbons, a short skirt of raw silk with many tiny pleats, scarlet stockings, and embroidered silk slippers.

In addition to the special furnishings of her wedding day, Lucia wore the everyday ornament of a modest beauty, enhanced and heightened by the various emotions painted on her face: a joyfulness tempered by a slight restlessness, the placid, rueful sorrow that often appears on the faces of brides and, without marring their beauty, gives them a special character.
Little Bettina pushed her way through the cluster of women. She went up to Lucia and whispered the message into her ear.
“I’ll be gone for just a second,” Lucia said to the women, and hurried downstairs.
At the sight of Renzo’s disturbed expression and nervous manner, she asked, “What is it?” not without a sense of dread.
“Lucia,” Renzo burst out, “everything is called off for today, and God only knows when we can become man and wife.”
“What?” cried Lucia in shock.
Renzo briefly related the events of the morning. She listened, filled with anguish, and when she heard Don Rodrigo’s name she exclaimed, “Ah”—turning red and trembling—“he went to these lengths!”
“So you knew…?” asked Renzo.
“Yes, unfortunately,” Lucia replied, “but I never thought he’d go so far!”
“What did you know?”
“Please don’t make me talk right now; don’t make me cry.
Let me run to get my mother and send the women away. We need to be alone.”
As she was leaving, Renzo muttered, “You never told me.”
“Oh, Renzo!” Lucia replied, turning toward him for a moment without stopping.
Renzo knew that her uttering his name at that moment, in that tone of voice, meant: “How can you doubt that I kept quiet for anything other than the purest and most honest reasons?”

Meanwhile the good Agnese (as Lucia’s mother was called), whose suspicion and curiosity had been raised by that whisper in the ear and the disappearance of her daughter, went downstairs to find out what had happened.

Her daughter left her alone with Renzo and went back to where the women were gathered. Fixing her appearance and her voice as best she could, she said, “The priest has taken sick, so nothing can be done today.”
With that, she quickly wished them on their way and went back downstairs.
The women filed out and then scattered through the village to talk about what had just happened.
Two or three of them even went all the way to the priest’s door, to check and see whether he really was ill.

“A high fever!” Perpetua replied from the window. This sad word, reported to the others, cut short the conjectures that were already starting to ferment in their brains or express themselves in mysterious bits and pieces.
